title: Lonely Planet
label: Running Back
description: The Australian producer’s new mini-album is his most fully realized work yet, and also his most original. It mostly ignores the dancefloor in favor of resting pulses and humid atmospheres.

title: I Said No Doctors!
label: Dymaxion Groove
description: This compilation gathers experimental musicians like Dan Deacon, David Grubbs, Senyawa and others, all of whom explore the strange sounds they can make from eccentric instruments.

title: Twin Peaks: Fire Walk With Me OST
label: Death Waltz
description: Angelo Badalamenti’s soundtrack for David Lynch’s 1992 “Twin Peaks” film Fire Walk With Me remains as enchanting and evocative as ever, and gets a long overdue vinyl reissue courtesy of Death Waltz.

title: Jardín
label: Stones Throw
description: Gabriel Garzón-Montano became famous when Drake sampled his voice for “Jungle,” but his debut album stands on its own, heavy on pearly funk and pop, live instrumentation and harmony.

title: The Grateful Dead: 50th Anniversary Deluxe Edition
label: Rhino
description: At the time of their endearing-but-muddy self-titled debut, “San Francisco’s Grateful Dead” were already local legends, but no one quite knew what to do with them on record.

title: Raw Light II
label: Western Vinyl
description: The Austin-based producer Spencer Stephenson (aka Botany) builds his music, made from loosely interlocking samples and loops, like a collage artist.

title: Trust Me EP
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Scandinavian house and disco producer Mr. Tophat recruits his superstar compatriot Robyn for a three-song EP.

title: Anything Could Happen
label: Fat Possum
description: Anything Could Happen is the first album in 24 years from Bash & Pop, Tommy Stinson’s short-lived post-Replacements outfit. It’s less an exercise in reliving the past than coming to terms with it.

title: Oczy Mlody
label: Warner Bros.
description: Miley Cyrus only appears once on the Flaming Lips’ claustrophobic new full-length, but the record wouldn’t sound the way it does without her presence in their lives.

title: Foxhole
label: Slumberland
description: This ’60s-loving London band, featuring former Veronica Falls member James Hoare, craft beguilingly simple, guitar-driven psych-pop. The new LP is a warm blanket of analog guitar and woolly harmony.

title: Love If Possible
label: Zelone
description: Former Yura Yura Teikoku guitarist continues lap steel-dappled explorations of melancholy, funky kitsch.

title: Music to Draw to: Satellite
label: Arts & Crafts
description: Veteran Montreal DJ Kid Koala steps away from the turntables for an album of cosmic-themed ambient pop, assisted by Icelandic singer-songwriter Emilíana Torrini.

title: Compilation LP
label: Wilsuns RC
description: Compilation LP is a remastered suite of the fiery Philly punk five-piece’s three EPs to date. The 40-minute record hurtles ahead, a swarm of righteous energy with hooks in every corner.

title: Changer
label: Polyvinyl
description: In the last year, indie rock lifer Fred Thomas got married, quit his day job, and moved to Canada, but *Changer *isn’t about that. It’s about getting older and how the weight of expectations is a bitch.

title: Scenes of the Tourist
label: self-released
description: Brooklyn-based songwriter Kyle Wall (aka Wharfer) makes his influences immediately clear—Bill Callahan, Lambchop’s Kurt Wagner, later Bob Dylan—but he doesn't really sound like anyone else.

title: He's Got the Whole This Land Is Your Land in His Hands
label: Joyful Noise
description: Joan of Arc’s latest troll manifesto offers a nasty reminder of Tim Kinsella’s ability to ruffle feathers, playing up one of his most off-putting qualities: his humor.

title: Luck Man
label: Sinderlyn
description: Tim Cohen, frontman of the Fresh & Onlys, is at his most modest and self-effacing here, building quiet, quirky songs out of acoustic guitars, soft percussion, and accents of piano and synth.

title: Mountain Rock
label: Orindal
description: In 2004, Katy Davidson infused her indie-pop project Dear Nora—an influence on the likes of Girlpool and Joyce Manor—with a windswept folk sensibility. Her most complex album is newly reissued.

title: Hang
label: Jagjaguwar
description: On their last album, Foxygen sounded like a band trying to survive. On their latest, they reach for the sky, making an audacious timpani crash of an album that satirizes its own grandiosity.

title: Hear the Lions Roar
label: Fire
description: Four decades in, Jad Fair retains his innocent abandon on Half Japanese’s sixteenth studio album Hear the Lions Roar.

title: Wake in Fright
label: Sacred Bones
description: Uniform is the industrial metal duo of vocalist Michael Berdan and guitarist/programmer Ben Greenberg. Their fevered, relentless sophomore record is the sound of clawing for survival and sanity.

title: Germfree Adolescents
label: EMI
description: X-Ray Spex’s debut album is a brash, vivid masterpiece of the germinal punk era. Its songs tackle identity, feminism, and consumer society with fire and joy.

label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: The underrated British folk icon Michael Chapman collaborates with Steve Gunn on what he is calling his “American” album.

title: Live - Meadowbrook, Rochester, Michigan - 12th September 1971
label: Tidal Waves
description: This just-reissued live album is not simply P-Funk in its early phase—it’s P-Funk in transition. Having hardly rehearsed with two new members, Meadowbrook captures moments of barely controlled chaos.

title: Migration
label: Ninja Tune
description: Bonobo’s early records were slightly hazy and indistinct, but Migration is the most sophisticated effort of his career.

title: Machine Messiah
label: Nuclear Blast
description: Machine Messiah skirts the line between metal and conventional “hard rock” more than anything in the Sepultura catalog.

title: Chixtape 4 / The New Toronto 2
label: self-released
description: Rapper/singer Tory Lanez’s primary skill is mimicking others, and on a new pair of mixtapes, the rule seems to be: If it ain't broke, add new drums and put it out again.

title: A Shadow in Time
description: Basinski's new album *A Shadow in Time *contains some of his strongest work since The Disintegration Loops introduced him to the world at large.

title: Two Zero One Seven
label: Glory Boyz
description: Chief Keef fittingly teams with trap architect Lex Luger for his daring new 17-song tape, which is weird and expansive. It reintroduces many of Keef’s most compelling quirks.

title: Brothers
label: self-released
description: *Brothers *is a snapshot of two young producers—Suicideyear and Outthepound—evolving quickly. They both favor languid tempos and nostalgic synth tones, and their work has a druggy, melancholic feel.

title: Iris OST
artist: A Winged Victory for the Sullen
label: Erased Tapes
description: The duo of Adam Wiltzie (also of Stars of the Lid) and Dustin O’Halloran take their cosmic drones to the score for a French erotic thriller called Iris.

title: Gentlewoman, Ruby Man
label: Glassnote
description: Part of the fun of this covers album from the Spacebomb Records crew is hearing how Matthew E. White and Flo Morrissey rethink how male and female voices can relate and react to each other.

title: I See You
label: Young Turks
description: I See You, the third album by the xx, attempts to incorporate everyone’s talents into a new version of their sound, one true to their roots but richer and more varied.

title: AFI (The Blood Album)
label: Concord Music Group
description: The timing couldn’t be better for AFI’s triumphant comeback; instead, they just sorta came back. This new LP works a “back to basics” operating principle, but it’s a “basics” that doesn’t serve them.

title: The Fragile (2017 Definitive Edition) / The Fragile: Deviations 1
label: The Null Corporation
description: In its newly remastered and rereleased incarnation, Trent Reznor's 1999 magnum opus *The Fragile *scrapes the sky like never before. Its companion, a reworking called Deviations 1, is mostly a curio.

title: As Was
label: Relapse
description: Like Celtic Frost before them, Black Anvil find ways to summon profound darkness without tapping into black-metal clichés. Their latest ebbs and flows with effortless grace.

title: White Friday (CM9)
label: Epic
description: After the late-career smash “Down in the DM,” Yo Gotti reinvigorates his long-running Cocaine Muzik series, serving his usual street fare with a bit more polish. It is a snapshot of Gotti in stride.

title: Of Murk and Shallow Water EP
label: self-released
description: The duo of 9T Antiope smashes together sounds from antiquity—singing reminiscent of medieval European folk, lyrics full of chariot and faeries—with hurtling production from the digital future.

title: Hélices EP
label: Salviatek
description: The debut EP by Brazilian producer Superfície uses morphing club sounds to soundtrack a politically-charged sci-fi narrative of his country’s past, present, and future.

title: The Natural
label: self-released
description: The Natural is the best of Kool A.D.’s 10 (!) projects released in 2016, setting aside his deconstructive tendencies in favor of structured songs with intriguing, clever, and funny rhymes.

title: Duo (DCWM) 2013
label: RogueArt
description: Saxophonist Anthony Braxton's collaboration with koto player Miya Masaoka is simultaneously dramatic and dreamy, swinging between free improv and ambient passages.

title: Doing It in Lagos: Boogie, Pop & Disco in 1980s Nigeria
label: Soundway
description: This prescient reissue delivers a crucial set of Nigerian songs that show the country absorbing and beaming back singular versions of disco, boogie, electro, and early rap.

title: Strictly 4 My Fans
label: self-released
description: G Herbo remains rap’s youngest old man, a wizened 21-year-old who sounds, for the third year running, like he’s on the cusp of something truly great.

title: Forever
label: Roadrunner
description: With their third LP and major-label debut, the hardcore band Code Orange offer up compelling, caustic, and occasionally even catchy evidence that they have earned their alpha-dog scene posturing.

title: Us or Else: Letter to the System
label: Grand Hustle
description: T.I.'s political tenth studio album presents itself as a warning to black Americans who find themselves labeled social disruptors for simply trying to live their lives harmoniously.

title: Cockfighters EP
label: Matador
description: After a 20-year hiatus, this concise new Chavez EP arrives with little fanfare, drawing in a trancelike sound and Eastern-inspired melodies.

title: Mezzanine
label: Virgin
description: On Mezzanine, Massive Attack tried to escape trip-hop. They nearly tore themselves apart and made its defining document instead.

title: All of Them Naturals
label: Static Shock
description: The second EP from these Minneapolis punks is a well-honed collection of crude, soured rock and sardonic humor.

title: Prelapsarian
label: Hathenter
description: Prelapsarian is the most compact of the New York-based metal band's albums. On these dense thirty-five minutes, they have both feet planted on terra firma and are racing against the doomsday clock.

title: First Songs
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: First Songs collects Kleenex’s output from 1978 to 1982. Their gleefully anarchic music still feels like liberation, reveling in the limitless freedom that comes with tossing logic aside.

title: New Start
label: Teklife
description: Taso’s new EP features collaborations with DJ Spinn and the late DJ Rashad, at times evoking the latter’s legendary album Double Cup.

title: Insecure (Music From the HBO Original Series)
label: RCA
description: Solange Knowles curates the soundtrack to the critically lauded HBO comedy “Insecure.” The 16 songs, mostly by or about women and almost exclusively by black artists, effortlessly mix R&B and rap.

title: Tehillim
label: Stroboscopic Artefacts
description: The Tel Aviv-based electronic music producer Yotam Avni mines the trenches between tech, tribal and deep house, adding in choral elements that mingle the ancient with the futuristic.

title: Stillness in Wonderland
label: Age 101
description: The prolific rapper Little Simz returns with a concept album that references Alice in Wonderland.

title: Filthy America… It’s Beautiful
label: Roc Nation
description: On their first project in 17 years, the voices and the wordplay of Styles P, Jadakiss, and Sheek Louch have aged not one bit since 2000, for better and for worse.

title: Reflection
label: Warp
description: Eno's new ambient piece readily slots along works like the dreamlike Thursday Afternoon and 2012’s stately Lux. It feels the most pensive of his ambient works, flowing across 54 unbroken minutes.

title: Clear Sounds/Perfetta
label: Important
description: The late sculptor Harry Bertoia became a drone musician almost by chance, making tactile sound-art out of metal rods before his death in 1978. These previously unreleased recordings befit his legacy.

title: Nadir
label: Pan
description: On his austere fourth full-length, the Berlin-based electronic artist Steven Warwick uses ambient synth sketches to convey feelings of precarity and millennial abjection.

title: Run the Jewels 3
label: self-released
description: RTJ3 is essentially the Run the Jewels manifesto, an outpouring of rage and defiance that never loses sight of the objectives: rallying the troops, holding all accountable, and toppling oppression.

title: Don’t Smoke Rock
label: Babygrande
description: New York hip-hop godfather Pete Rock joins forces with Smoke DZA on an album of uptown cool and crisp soul.

title: December 99th
label: A Country Called Earth
description: On December 99th, Yasiin Bey (fka Mos Def) sounds like he no longer believes his own words, or he’s tired of hearing himself say them. It is by far the worst thing he’s ever released.

title: Brønshøj (Puncak)
label: Cejero
description: Fusing folk, doom metal, and improv noise, the Indonesian duo Senyawa are unlike any other band. The five songs of their new LP are drawn out and meditative, admitting little daylight.

title: Punk45: Les Punks: The French Connection (The First Wave of French Punk 1977-80)
label: Soul Jazz
description: Soul Jazz’s Punk 45 series has made it its mission to chart the forgotten corners of punk rock, and the latest version explores what happened when punk landed in mainland Europe.

title: Merry Christmas Lil’ Mama
label: self-released
description: Chance the Rapper and Jeremih’s surprise release is a Christmas album for the final yuletide of the Obama administration: one last bastion of hope in an uncertain and fraught time.

title: ///// Effectual
label: Leaving
description: On his solo percussion LP, Jamire Williams shows himself to be an inspired crafter of sound, capable of building entire worlds from just his drum hits.

title: Love You to Death
label: Radio Killa
description: The undervalued singer/songwriter/producer offers a bedroom-friendly five-track EP filled with slow-motion songs about lust, desire, and regret.

title: What Graceless Dawn
label: Profound Lore
description: On their earthy new album, the Bay Area metal trio Worm Ouroboros exhibit a literary flair and mysterious, eternal power.

title: Holy Science
label: Northern Spy
description: A fixture of New York’s experimental scene, the vocalist Amirtha Kidambi makes her bandleading debut on Holy Science, fusing classical Indian music, drone, and free jazz with an original perspective.

title: Not the Actual Events EP
label: self-released
description: Nine Inch Nails’ surprise-release new EP Not the Actual Events is slight, but at moments it delivers the kind of visceral fury that NIN hasn’t recreated since its mid-’90s Downward Spiral heyday.

title: The Wasp Factory
label: Bedroom Community
description: In 2013, the composer Ben Frost and librettist David Pountney devised an unconventional opera piece inspired by the 1984 psychological horror novel The Wasp Factory. Its music is shockingly beautiful.

title: EARLY TAPES, 1996-1998
label: P.W. Elverum & Sun
description: Even though this collection of unreleased songs and rarities is slight, it testifies to the enduring power of the Microphones, and how they represented a thriving part of Pacific Northwest indie.

title: Traditional Music of Notional Species Vol. II
label: Pan
description: The second volume in Rashad Becker’s series is redolent of Smithsonian Folkways’ field recordings, with nods to early musique concrète and intercepted extraterrestrial transmissions.

title: A Very Kacey Christmas
label: Mercury
description: Kacey Musgraves' first holiday album summons ‘60s nostalgia, embraces kitschy exotica, and passes the pipe with Willie Nelson.

title: Turn Into
label: Polyvinyl
description: Melina Duterte is a San Francisco musician who performs as Jay Som. She plays every instrument on her album Turn Into, a kaleidoscopic collection of dream pop touching on multiple moods.

title: The Great Southern Trendkill
label: Rhino
description: Intended as a rallying cry against shifting trends, Pantera's most abrasive album comes off more like a cry for help that reveals the turmoil eating the band from within. It's also thrilling.

title: Swiss Radio Days Vol. 41 - Zurich 1961
label: Challenge
description: A new Ray Charles reissue finds the maestro in thrilling form in Switzerland—and those Quincy Jones charts are just gravy.

title: Do What Thou Wilt.
label: Top Dawg
description: On his latest, syllable-twisting conspiracy theorist Ab-Soul becomes so information-obsessed that he loses sight of actual meaning. The songs are empty riddles, leading nowhere and saying nothing.

title: The Return of East Atlanta Santa
label: 1017 Brick Squad
description: The Return of East Atlanta Santa leans on the lighter, more playful side of Gucci’s personality. You can hear him settling into his clean post-prison lifestyle and his new, clearer voice.

title: Jackie OST
label: Milan
description: With the power of an orchestra behind her, Mica Levi provides a melancholy pulse for Jackie's portrait of a seemingly unknowable historical figure.

title: Passion, Pain & Demon Slayin’
label: Republic
description: Scott Mescudi’s latest tome, the 87-minute Passion, Pain & Demon Slayin’, is the most focused he’s sounded since 2010’s Man on the Moon II, with the same drawbacks that have always plagued him.

title: Pieces in Space
label: Don Giovanni
description: The Ithaca, N.Y. rapper/producer Sammus writes at the intersection of race, womanhood, sexuality, and nerdiness. Pieces in Space is her strongest work to date.

title: Slight Freedom
label: Eremite
description: Restraint prevails on the debut solo record from Tortoise’s Jeff Parker—a collection of quiet, atmospheric mood studies that seems to hang in mid-air.

title: Fireplace: TheNotTheOtherSide
label: Columbia
description: After years of mixtapes, erstwhile Odd Future rapper and MellowHype MC releases his debut album. He sounds completely unmoored, stuck somewhere between punchline rapper, storyteller, and moralist.

title: In the Loop: A Decade of Remixes
label: Fool's Gold
description: The lavish In the Loop 6x7” box set collects A-Trak’s remix work. Listening to all of them at once reveals that he often tried to please everyone, and also that he intermittently succeeded.

title: Throat
label: Pan
description: Aaron David Ross’s latest as ADR is composed of vocal samples, most scrubbed clean of any signifiers of human origin. The effect is amusing, even creepy, and recalls Holly Herndon or Katie Gately.

title: Heart Song
label: Brutal Honest
description: Texan singer/songwriter Jess Williamson ditches the bucolic sound of her stark debut for a haunted urban malaise that feels far more natural for her.

title: American Boyfriend: A Suburban Love Story
label: BROCKHAMPTON
description: Kevin Abstract seems like an endearing alt-rock frontman in a rapper's body. On American Boyfriend, his sophomore album, he explores the insecurities and ravages of his high school years.

title: Chronology
label: New Amsterdam
description: Dawn of Midi drummer Qasim Naqvi's latest EP unearths new, ambient-influenced grooves with a vintage Moog.

title: Oh No No No Remixes EP
label: Hyperdub
description: Jessy Lanza’s new EP features remixes from former collaborators and tourmates DJ Taye and DJ Spinn of Chicago footwork crew Teklife, Morgan Geist aka Storm Queen, and Leon Smart as DVA [Hi:Emotions].

title: W:/2016ALBUM/
label: mau5trap
description: On his latest, EDM titan deadmau5 continues to hint that he might have a better, richer album in him. Once more, he has not made it.

title: Grunewald
label: Erased Tapes
description: Composer Peter Broderick manages to make simple, beautiful post-classical music with a distinctive personality. His new EP collects five tracks taken from a single day’s live recording in Berlin.

title: Melo de Melo EP
label: Drumma
description: On this two-track EP, Ricardo Villalobos teams with fellow Chilean producer Umho to celebrate their shared love of Latin American music.

title: Equality Now EP
label: Numbers
description: Peder Mannerfelt has produced groups like Fever Ray and Blonde Redhead. On his new EP, he channels his interest in emancipatory politics and exotic rhythms into crisp, clever tracks.

title: Bob Dylan: The 1966 Live Recordings
label: Columbia Legacy
description: This 36-disc box set presents every surviving tape of Bob Dylan's 1966 world tour, capturing combative audiences and transcendent performances nearly every night.

title: Stoney
label: Republic
description: Following the success of his viral hit “White Iverson,” Post Malone releases a 68-minute album that shows exactly why he should have never been given the chance to release a 68-minute album.

title: Hologram İmparatorluğu
label: Glitterbeat
description: The Turkish singer Gaye Su Akyol has emerged at the fore of her country’s revitalized music scene in recent years. Her new album mixes Turkish modes and scales with grunge, surf rock, and psychedelia.

title: Skin Companion EP I
label: Mom & Pop
description: After rocketing into the stratosphere with his first album and struggling with second album syndrome, Australian producer Flume scales back with a lithe, quirky, understated EP.

title: 4 Your Eyez Only
label: Roc Nation
description: On J. Cole’s fourth album, he wrestles with the fragility of life and the importance of family ties.  He also sands down some of his worst impulses.

title: The Early Years 1965-1972
label: Legacy
description: This massive box set captures the British art-rock legends’ progression from Syd Barrett’s cracked-out psychedelia through the experimental song suites of the early 1970s.

title: Sketches for My Sweetheart the Drunk
label: Columbia
description: Jeff Buckley died before completing his second album. Sketches for My Sweetheart the Drunk, compiling those sessions, gives a glimpse into an erratic mind that could be too mercurial for its own good.

title: Bucket List Project
label: self-released
description: Chicago rapper Saba is a frequent collaborator with Chance the Rapper. His latest mixtape, Bucket List Project, is about the experiences we long to pack into one lifetime.

title: The Hamilton Mixtape
label: Atlantic
description: On The Hamilton Mixtape, songs from the iconic musical have been reinterpreted by Nas, Jill Scott, Alicia Keys, Chance the Rapper, and others, for some reason.

title: Welcome To Sideways
label: Delicacies
description: Simian Mobile Disco have survived past the death of their microgenre ”bloghouse.” Their latest album is a study in dance music rather than a practice, a suite that demands to be heard in one sitting.

title: Bobo Yéyé: Belle Époque in Upper Volta
label: Numero Group
description: Across three discs of rough-hewed yet honeyed music, this three-disc set captures the cosmopolitan scene of Africa’s post-colonial Upper Volta in the 1960s and ’70s.

title: Africa Express Presents... The Orchestra of Syrian Musicians & Guests
label: Transgressive
description: Damon Albarn and Africa Express organized this concert with 50 musicians from the Syrian National Orchestra. Featuring Julia Holter, Albarn, and others, it reaffirms that art at its best is a gesture of empathy.

title: Blessed Initiative
label: Subtext
description: As Blessed Initiative, experimental producer and sound artist Yair Elazar Glotman explores some deeply uncomfortable and unsettling spaces. But there is a strange and beautiful majesty to his work.

title: Zero Gravity EP
label: Epic
description: The Atlanta rapper and singer Kodie Shane is the most talented member of Lil Yachty’s motley crew, and on this EP—a bite-sized compilation of old tracks and new ones—everything clicks.

title: BOX
label: Kompakt
description: Nearly twenty years later, Wolfgang Voigt’s records under the GAS alias still assault our presumptions about electronic music. How can music that seems to be monotonous convey such beauty and clarity?

title: Relationships
label: Fool's Gold
description: On his debut full-length, the Brooklyn producer invites a wide range of guests over for a genre-spanning studio party. 21 Savage, Hudson Mohawke, DJ Rashad and the Deftones’ Chino Moreno feature.

title: Peace Trail
label: Reprise
description: The ten sparse protest songs on Neil Young's strange and scrappy new album address the dissemination of fake news, the mistreatment of America’s indigenous people, and the water crisis in Flint.

title: Der Klang der Offenbarung des Göttlichen
label: Bel-Air Glamour Records
description: After spending fifteen years as a member of Sigur Rós, composer Kjartan Sveinsson makes the leap into classical with a sweeping, elegiac orchestral and choral score.

title: Badmotorfinger
label: A&M
description: Soundgarden's Badmotorfinger captures the band clicking on all cylinders. The album sustains a level of focus, cohesion, and intensity that the band’s later, more varied albums lack.

title: How to Disappear in America
label: White Material
description: Techno artist and White Material label cofounder Young Male branches off from floor fillers on his latest. This is dank, ominous, beat-free music that suggests a certain weary fatalism.

title: Blue & Lonesome
label: Polydor
description: On their bashed-out new album of blues covers, the Stones sound, for the first time in eons, like a band playing together in the same room rather than one that travels on separate jets.

title: Harlequin
label: Domino
description: A modernist spin on the ’70s singer-songwriter album, Harlequin often seems torn between its ambition and its nonchalance, a mix of perplexing quirks and disarming heart.

title: 1017 vs. the World
label: 1017 Brick Squad
description: On their new collaborative 7-song mixtape, Lil Uzi Vert and Gucci Mane have a Who Framed Roger Rabbit dynamic, where Uzi is the elastic Roger and Gucci the human detective Eddie Valiant.

title: The Weight of These Wings
label: Sony
description: Miranda Lambert’s double album arrives in the wake of her high-profile divorce from Blake Shelton, but it is refreshingly devoid of spite or anger—more “Shelter From the Storm” than “Idiot Wind.”

title: love and noir.
label: Input
description: This Brooklyn duo traffics in spare, low-lit R&B, its elements bleeding together or blurring just out of focus.

title: Zoovier
label: self-released
description: Fetty Wap’s new tape doesn't quite answer the question of whether the New Jersey rapper will sustain his success or remain “Trap Queen Guy” forevermore.

title: “Awaken, My Love!”
label: Glassnote
description: On Donald Glover’s latest project as Childish Gambino, he ditches rap for lovingly produced funk worship, resulting in his most enjoyable project yet.

title: Only Heaven
label: Ahead of Our Time
description: On this new EP, the British electronic duo and Ninja Tune label founders reckon with the disorientation of our media moment. Their approach is unfortunately vague.

title: Darkness and Light
label: Columbia
description: On Darkness and Light, John Legend pushes beyond his comfort zone for something a bit more ambitious.  This is a love record about navigating the bleak world and finding happiness in dark times.

title: Unfinished Music No. 1: Two Virgins / Unfinished Music No. 2: Life With the Lions / Yoko Ono Plastic Ono Band
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Yoko Ono’s radical influence on pop history has inspired generations of visionary musicians. Deeply rooted in Fluxus, Ono’s newly-reissued early albums help to detail her broader artistic intentions.

title: Let It Be You
label: Reveal
description: On their collaboration, singer-songwriter Joan Wasser of Joan as Police Woman and Benjamin Lazar Davis of the chamber pop outfit Cuddle Magic bond over their fascination with big, mainstream pop.

title: The Devil and God Are Raging Inside Me
label: Interscope
description: Brand New's The Devil and God Are Raging Inside Me blew up teen angst to literally biblical proportions, resonating like no emo band before or since to outcasts in Sunday school *and *high school.

title: Singles
label: Strut
description: Strut offers a richly researched and smartly sequenced compilation of all of Sun Ra's singles, offering a compelling and unique look at the cosmic jazz innovator’s genius.

title: Remain Calm
label: Slipdisc
description: On this collaborative LP, Mica Levi (Micachu & the Shapes) pairs with the cellist Oliver Coates (a contributor to Radiohead’s A Moon Shaped Pool) for one of 2016’s more enjoyable experimental albums.

title: Häxan
label: Mexican Summer
description: Häxan is the first instrumental effort by the psych-rock band Dungen, a scoring of the 1926 animation classic The Adventures of Prince Achmed.

title: Broken Knowz
label: Technicolour
description: The Detroit techno and house producer Jay Daniel expands outward, embracing his role as percussionist and folding vibrant live textures into his sound.

title: Keita Sano
label: Rett I Fletta
description: Keita Sano is the Japanese producer's most grounded and focused work yet. These tracks fit into no particular paradigm or scene; they are stuffed with ideas, all of which hope to make you dance.

title: Out of Time
label: Concord Bicycle
description: Along with Nevermind, released a half year later, R.E.M.’s Out of Time was the early-’90s major-label ideal: A blockbuster that multiplied the band’s following without losing existing fans.

title: Amore Per Tutti
label: NNA Tapes
description: The 14-piece ensemble Tredici Bacci pays loving and exacting tribute to the lush spaghetti western scores of Ennio Morricone without getting musty or dull: This is reverent, goofy, and fun music.

title: 24K Magic
label: Atlantic
description: On his latest, “Uptown Funk” vocalist and animatronic sequined suit Bruno Mars compresses all of his various personae into one: The retro song-and-dance man who happens to be really, really horny.

title: Young Death / Nightmarket
label: Hyperdub
description: Burial's latest EP has a wispy, vaporous quality, evoking a liminal space between events, a present moment all about suggestion.

title: Abendrot
label: Triple Crown
description: The latest record from emo outfit You Blew It! is their most subdued yet, trading pop-punk yelps for the smoothly layered guitars of Mineral and American Football.

title: Red Friday
label: Def Jam
description: On his new new seven-song EP, dropped on short notice, YG is back on full throttle, racing ahead and sounding more nimble than ever.

title: What You Get for Being Young
label: Melody As Truth
description: This gently melancholic album from the ambient artist Suzanne Kraft offers solace while rejecting the soporific.

title: Six Pianos / Keyboard Study #1
label: Forced Exposure
description: Berlin's FILM Recordings offers a new recording of two golden-era works by the minimalist masters, reimagined and modernized.

title: PC Music, Vol. 2
label: PC Music
description: Cobbling together styles from Top 40 and the dance underground alike, Vol. 2 raises the question: Can a microgenre that’s all self-consciously hyper-“contemporary” veneer sustain itself long-term?

title: Mystery Cove
label: Gold Robot
description: Mystery Cove, the fourth Monster Rally full-length, is pure, distilled escapism: 42 straight minutes of somewhere else, no SPF required. It is a Hawaiian shirt with an AUX input.

title: Starboy
label: Republic
description: With Beauty Behind the Madness, Abel Tesfaye achieved pop stardom without compromising his vision. On its uninspired follow-up, Starboy, he seems to lose sight of that vision almost entirely.

title: L.A. Heartbreak
label: Time No Place
description: The electro-punk duo Rainbow Arabia make their smoothest, most pop-friendly, and sophisticated statement yet.

title: Wonderland
label: Modern Love
description: Continuing the beat-oriented experiments of their 12” club tunes, the electronic duo Demdike Stare blend their doomy aesthetic with dancehall cadences for their most compelling full-length.

title: Woman
label: Ed Banger
description: With Woman, Justice attempt the sort of analog nostalgia trip Daft Punk pulled off on Random Access Memories. Have the enfants terribles of French house grown up?

title: Defy a Thing to Be
label: Vague Terrain
description: The debut release from queer multimedia artist Bully Fae, on Matmos' Vague Terrain label, mixes rapping, stand-up comedy, spoken-word, and more into a hilarious and fascinating whole.

title: On Behalf of Nature
label: ECM New Series
description: Meredith Monk's influence as a singer and composer extends through Björk, Joanna Newsom and beyond. On Behalf of Nature is a plea for ecological awareness with no lectures, just beauty and empathy.

title: Sixth Stitch
label: Break World
description: New York’s Dylan Scheer, who DJs and produces as Via App, specializes in channeling noise, chaos, and discomfort into tracks that still work on the dancefloor.

title: The D-Boy Diary Books 1 & 2
label: Heavy on the Grind
description: After a relatively quiet 2015, the Bay Area legend returns to his firehose production methods, dropping another slab of new material. But there's an increasing sense that he's repeating himself.

title: Young Narrator in the Breakers
label: Bella Union
description: Pavo Pavo's debut LP sounds like a dispatch from what people in the mid-20th century thought the future would be like: jetpacks, Mars landings and dehydrated Thanksgiving dinners.

title: Before the Dawn
label: Fish People
description: This 155-minute, three-disc live album documents Kate Bush’s spectacular 2014 live shows, her first in 35 years. She reckons with her legacy through what might seem like an obscure setlist.

title: Death Certificate
label: Priority
description: Death Certificate is Ice Cube’s most important (if not his best) album, and one of the most essential works in rap history.

title: Redemption
label: Local Action
description: Redemption concludes Dawn Richard's trilogy. If Goldenheart was aggressive and Blackheart depressive, Redemption is reflective, an unusual headspace for a dance floor album to inhabit.

title: Vergers
label: Important
description: Sarah Davachi's minimalist work belongs to a tradition of deep, shimmering drone music. Play her music in a quiet room on good speakers and you can practically see the air moving around your head.

title: What’s Your Sign?
label: Northern Spy
description: This collaborative album from the punk-influenced composer Rhys Chatham and Brooklyn noise-jam heroes Oneida builds on power and cosmic eruptions.

title: A O R T A
label: New Amsterdam
description: Avant-garde pianist Vicky Chow releases an album full of roving, tense compositions from modern-day composers, blending her traditional piano with blurs of digital effects and percussion.

title: WORRY.
label: SideOneDummy
description: In certain circles, Jeff Rosenstock is one of the most important figures in modern punk, and with WORRY., he has made his magnum opus.

title: Wyatt at the Coyote Palace
label: Omnibus
description: Hersh's latest solo album is a typically personal and idiosyncratic affair, rich with dense but frank allusions to the dissolution of her 25-year marriage.

title: Boots No. 1: The Official Revival Bootleg
label: Acony
description: On this collection of officially sanctioned archival bootlegs, we can hear the roots country icon Gillian Welch in the process of discovering and honing her inimitable voice.

title: Free Bricks 2: Zone 6 Edition
label: self-released
description: The here-then-gone-again collaborative Gucci/Future mixtape *Free Bricks 2 *is the sound of two superlative talents working without boundaries.

title: Daniel Bachman
label: Three Lobed
description: Acoustic guitarist Daniel Bachman's second self-titled album is his most thoughtful release to date, filled with mindful reflection, confident patience, and a sense of ecological awareness.

title: Hardwired...to Self-Destruct
label: Blackened Recordings
description: Like Death Magnetic, Metallica’s latest is an attempt to revisit their early days. The only difference is that this time they sound like they’re actually trying, and maybe even having a bit of fun.

title: Shadow Boat EP
label: Tresor
description: On their first new record in 17 years, the music of dub techno pioneers Porter Ricks has hardly changed, and really, that's for the best.

title: “ring spiel” tour ’95
label: Legacy
description: This live album captures one night in the unlikely, alt-rock-superstar-laden tour behind Minutemen legend Mike Watt's first solo album, featuring Eddie Vedder, Dave Grohl, and more.

title: Flasher EP
label: Sister Polygon
description: On their debut EP, the Washington, DC post-punk trio Flasher offer seven impressively-honed songs that speak to selfhood and sublimation.

title: Incunabula / Amber / Tri Repetae
label: Warp
description: Revisiting electronic pioneers Autechre’s earliest albums, now reissued, is like returning to a previously uninhabitable planet and being startled to find residents living and thriving there.

title: On Dark Silent Off
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The tactile and heartfelt fifth album by the instrumental Austrian trio Radian doesn’t simply reward repeated listens, it demands them.

title: No Waves
label: Matador
description: This live set captures Body/Head (improvisational guitarist Bill Nace and Kim Gordon) operating at a furious peak, reeling from no-wave to free jazz to pop hooks in an exhilarating blur.

title: Patterns of Light
label: London London
description: His Name Alive's new album is inspired by the Large Hadron Collider, filtering the cosmic implications of the awe-inspiring device through the stonier side of ‘70s rock.

title: I’m Your Man
label: Columbia
description: I’m Your Man reinvented Leonard Cohen at age 53. It is the most fun you can have while being told that life is a terrible joke.

title: The Microcosm: Visionary Music of Continental Europe, 1970-1986
label: Light in the Attic
description: The Microcosm is a sort of European answer to the influential new age comp I Am the Center. Featuring Vangelis, Hans-Joachim Roedelius and others, it draws lines between visionaries of many stripes.

title: Yaroze Dream Suite
label: Local Action
description: On this woozy collaborative EP, the grime producers Mr. Mitch and Yamaneko trade the genre’s brute force for restraint, drawing out subtle threads and small pockets of emotion.

title: Nightride
label: RCA
description: Tinashe's latest release is another helping of the moody, ominous R&B that she has quietly made her name on.

title: Highway Songs
label: Drag City
description: David Pajo's latest album as Papa M is wistful and poignant, like all his work. But it ultimately feels hopeful rather than weary, upbeat rather than defeated.

title: Luz
label: Leaving
description: Devonwho is part of the Klipmode collective that includes Leaving records labelmates MNDSGN and Knxwledge. His take on blunted instrumental hip-hop favors the wobbly synths of the early ’80s.

title: Persona EP
label: Warp
description: On his Warp debut, the Italian producer Lorenzo Senni deploys a Roland JP8000 synthesizer to isolate the builds and breakdowns of trance, to thrilling effect.

title: An Odd Entrances
label: Castle Face
description: Though it’s not a force of nature like the other LPs Thee Oh Sees have produced since returning from their farcically brief 2013 hiatus, Odd Entrances more than keeps their streak alive.

title: Telling It Like It Is
label: Sacred Bones
description: Marching Church used to be the solo effort of Iceage frontman Elias Bender Rønnenfelt, but now he has incorporated a backing band and scaled up the melodrama.

title: Ecologies II: Ecosystems of Excess
label: Knives
description: J.G. Biberkopf's Ecologies II: Ecosystems of Excess is an often fascinating record of music that sits between the club, gallery, and lecture hall. It stumbles most when it sounds like the last.

title: The Madness of Many
label: Sumerian
description: Animals as Leaders provide a dense and triumphant brand of instrumental metal that can be dazzling or exhausting, depending on your mood.

title: We got it from Here... Thank You 4 Your service
label: Epic
description: A Tribe Called Quest’s sixth (and final) album was a rumor for 18 years. It’s here, and against many odds, it reinvigorates the group’s discography without resting on nostalgia.

title: Slugger
label: Carpark
description: Speedy Ortiz's Sadie Dupuis steps out with a self-produced solo album that's all about positivity, in all caps and probably punctuated with multiple exclamation points.

title: $uccessor (ded004)
label: Hospital
description: On his first full-length as Dedekind Cut, the artist formerly known as Lee Bannon constructs an ambitious form of ambient music, reflecting the violence and anxiety pervading our atmosphere today.

title: &
label: !K7
description: On his third solo LP, the Cologne producer Michael Mayer collaborates with a different artist on each track. The album plays to his strengths, balancing strict grooves with faint hints of mischief.

title: Michael Gordon: Timber Remixed
label: Cantaloupe
description: On Timber Remixed, the likes of Tim Hecker, Fennesz, and Oneohtrix Point Never tackle Bang On a Can co-founder Michael Gordon’s driving and rhythmic work for wood planks.

title: Washington Phillips and His Manzarene Dreams
label: Dust-to-Digital
description: The life and music of gospel singer Washington Phillips has been shrouded in mystery for years. His gentle, measured, unearthly music, played on a handmade instrument,  is still a world unto itself.

title: Restless
label: Cantaloupe
description: The clarinetist and saxophonist Ken Thomson, whose roving works include covers of Björk and Meshuggah, records an album of minimalist chamber music full of feints and surprising paths.

title: Folk Time
label: ATO
description: Folk Time is the sound of Jerry Garcia and Robert Hunter absorbing their own set of influences, building their repertoires, and finding their voices.

title: MC4
label: Epic
description: In just over a decade of work, French Montana has gone from hanger-on to something more vital and far more interesting. MC4 is a reminder of why he’s been able to survive a couple sea changes in rap.

title: Long Live the Angels
label: Virgin
description: The British pop star Emeli Sandé writes power ballads that start at “cinematic” and scale upward. Her second album places that massive voice atop tracks of stately but interchangeable gloom.

title: Free the Real (Pt. 2)
label: Def Jam
description: The young German-Haitian singer-songwriter, who has famously written songs for Rihanna, basks in the gangly freedom of developing her own voice.

title: Holiday for Strings
label: Don Giovanni
description: The 78-year-old folk legend remains in a spirit full of joy, an embodiment of old-time string band chaos and a bastion of enthusiasm for the legacy of music as storytelling.

title: The Complete Sony Recordings
label: Sony Classical
description: This massive box set offers perhaps the definitive and most comprehensive collection of Philip Glass’ work ever assembled.

title: Amalgam
label: Northern Spy
description: An avant-garde cellist and a great turntablist collaborate on a 36-minute, fully improvised set that blurs the line between her strings and his samples.

title: Monument Builders
label: Kranky
description: The eleventh album from prolific ambient artist Scott Morgan maps a more human, and less quantifiable, concept: life’s resistance to dark and destructive forces.

title: Double Nickels on the Dime
label: SST
description: The Minutemen's classic double album is unlike any punk record, or double album, before or since. It is a compact explosion of ideas and a prism for the energies coursing through the ‘80s underground.

title: Ping Pong
label: Mag Mag
description: On their fourth full-length, Jacuzzi Boys’ ongoing transition from garage rock to slick pop remains hampered by their vacuous attitude.

title: Devil Music
label: We Are The Men
description: The Men retreat to their caustic roots with a raw and furious album that, while often predictable, is still a prime example of how well they rage.

title: Bleed for This OST
label: Milan
description: Ten of the eighteen tracks on the soundtrack for the Miles Teller-starring boxing film Bleed for This come courtesy of composer Julia Holter, in her first-ever film work.

title: Hubris
label: Editions Mego
description: Jim O’Rourke, Crys Cole, Keith Fullerton Whitman, Mark Fell, and Ricardo Villalobos all join Ambarchi on a dense and rewarding album that never succumbs to the weight of its collaborators.

title: Ded Sec - Watch Dogs 2 (OST)
label: Warp
description: Hudson Mohawke's gleaming soundtrack to the open-world action-adventure game Ded Sec - Watch Dogs 2 makes a surprisingly strong followup to his last proper full-length, last year's Lantern.

title: Systems/Layers
label: Quarterstick
description: Rachel's pioneered a blend of modern classical music and post-rock that you can hear in current practitioners Jóhann Jóhannsson and Max Richter. Their 2003 album Systems/Layers is their masterpiece.

title: Dead to the World
label: EarMusic
description: Page Hamilton takes more chances than he ever has on Dead to the World, Helmet's eighth studio album and fourth since he re-launched the brand with a revolving cast of side musicians.

title: Have a Nice Dream
label: DUM SHINY
description: In the last year, former Das Racist member Kool A.D. has released hundreds of tracks across multiple releases, and the latest zooms in on and explores a luxurious, off-kilter wooziness.

title: Ghosthouse
label: Sacred Bones
description: Uniform's sound is a marriage made in industrial-punk Hades, draping righteous pique over a grind lashed together from guitar groan and staple-gun electronics.

title: HERE
label: RCA
description: On her new album, Alicia Keys inhabits the personae of multiple characters but still doesn't tell us much about herself.

title: Arcade
label: New Funk Academy
description: Topaz Jones is a young, positive-thinking New York-based rapper with an affinity for soul and a likable and fully formed personality, and Arcade reveals quirks and depths with repeated listens.

title: Spaghetto
label: Warp
description: The London artist's latest is a protean collection of a new kind of reggae lovers rock record that finds power in its diverse, hybrid style.

title: Origin of What
label: In the Red
description: The Detroit punks Tyvek flex their mastery over their multifaceted sound on their new album—these wordy, detail-stuffed songs are fast and staid, intense and gentle, paranoid and curious.

title: Collage
label: Columbia
description: The massive lite-EDM duo the Chainsmokers portray themselves as hilariously repugnant caricatures, and on C**ollage, they paint a photorealist portrait of their manspread over the charts.

title: Lady, Give Me Your Key: The Unissued 1967 Solo Acoustic Sessions
label: Light in the Attic
description: A collection of stripped-down and unreleased tracks from the infamous folk singer's early days offers little clarity to his mercurial career, but these demos remain striking and emotional.

title: Away With You
label: Firehouse 12
description: The avant-garde guitarist expands her compositions to fit her largest group ever, creating one of the most intricate and entrancing sets of her career.

title: Trap or Die 3
label: Def Jam
description: On Trap or Die 3, Jeezy stops pretending to give a damn what listeners under 25 might be into, offering a back-to-basics statement despite never straying that far from the basics to begin with.

title: The Visitor
label: Fat Possum
description: The soul singer Kadjha Bonet offers a twisting, rich mix of psychedelia and soul on her plush debut album.

title: Jessica Rabbit
label: Torn Clean
description: Sleigh Bells' fourth record is a hodgepodge of clashing sounds and concepts that’s united only by its indiscriminate maximalism.

title: Soft Hair
label: Weird World
description: This collaboration between Connan Mockasin and Sam Dust, formerly of dance-punk Brits Late of the Pier, strikes a discomfiting balance between queasy and cute.

title: Lodestar
label: Domino
description: For her first record in 38 years, the wonderful British folk singer Shirley Collins dazzles with a collection of macabre and mischievous songs from centuries past.

title: Apocalypse Fetish
label: Joyful Noise
description: Following the solemn elegance of his last album Brace the Wave, Lou Barlow's new ukulele-heavy EP feels incomplete.

title: Eternally Even
label: Capitol
description: Jim James' new solo album contains some of his most psychedelic music, as well as his most directly topical lyrics, offering new ways for him to wield his otherworldly voice.

title: Romantic
label: Tiny Engines
description: Philadelphia’s Mannequin Pussy thrash swiftly from the playful to the chaotic. Their latest LP combines punk, shoegaze, death metal, and more, with the ferocious push-pull energy of a mosh pit.

title: Cozy Tapes Vol. 1: Friends-
label: RCA
description: The latest offering from A$AP Mob is really just an A$AP Rocky showcase, but per the title of the tape, he sounds more comfortable than ever, as do his compatriots. It’s natural and confident.

title: Arrival
label: Polar
description: At their best, as on Arrival, ABBA were as mysterious as Bowie, as rococo as Phil Spector, as unbearably sad as the Smiths.

title: The Deaner Album
label: ATO
description: Dean Ween's solo debut is missing the sincerity and surrealism of Ween, but its bizarre chaos feels like you are in on a longstanding inside joke with an old friend.

title: Liberation
label: Closed Sessions
description: oddCouple, a Chicago producer who has worked with Jamila Woods, Joey Purp, Saba, Kweku Collins, and others, gathers his most talented friends for a warm, relaxed affair full of pleasantly hazed beats.

title: Blunted on Reality
label: Music On Vinyl
description: On their underrated commercial-flop debut album, the Fugees searched energetically for the voice they would find on The Score.

title: Strange City
label: Cold Spring
description: The constant and destructive waves of noise make this decisively a Merzbow record, but its cosmic mood and rhythms prove that Sun Ra lives in its DNA.

title: You Know What It’s Like
label: Blackest Ever Black
description: Smoky and ominous, Australian singer/songwriter Carla dal Forno's You Know What It's Like simmers, both musically and thematically, while she inhabits the gloom of her arrangements like a ghost.

title: Keep Flexin
label: self-released
description: Rising Atlanta rapper and Migos affiliate Rich the Kid drops a bubbly, if not uninspired new tape with features from Young Thug, Desiigner, Migos, and Jeremih.

title: Black America Again
label: Def Jam
description: Common’s dissonant, politically-charged new album Black America Again finds him angry and off-balance—which feels like it’s exactly where he should be.

title: Talk to You Soon
label: Terrible
description: The latest from the experimental producer/songwriter dives into the warrens of memory and trauma with a collection of anxiety-ridden and often beautiful vignettes.

title: The Olympians
label: Daptone
description: This self-titled debut on Daptone Records follows a tried-and-true formula for the records: Hire incredible musicians and get out of their way.

title: QTT4
label: Quiet Time
description: Producer Huerco S.'s latest ambient release feels like something heard from the other end of a long, dark tunnel that you no longer remember how to find your way back across.

title: xxx
label: Big Deal
description: In a season where “pussy” has become a household word again for all the wrong reasons, Pussy Riot return to exact their vengeance. At least, that’s the narrative for Nadya Tolokno’s xxx EP.

title: Live at the Whiskey A Go Go: The Complete Recordings
label: Stax
description: This essential six-CD set captures Otis and his blazing ten-piece band at a vital time in soul music, where a young showman was trying to cross over to the white rock'n'rollers on the Sunset Strip.

title: Dissociation
label: Cooking Vinyl
description: The famously technical New Jersey band ends their career with one final album of squealing riffs, dizzying musicianship, and plenty of nostalgia for their heyday.

title: Freedom Jazz Dance: The Bootleg Series, Vol. 5
label: Columbia
description: A glimpse inside the studio for numerous outtakes and illuminating dialogue from the legendary “Second Great Quintet” sessions that would spawn Miles Davis' Miles Smiles, Nefertiti, and Water Babies.

title: DC4
label: Maybach
description: On the fourth installment of his Dreamchasers mixtape series, Meek struggles to figure out exactly where he belongs, caught between his old life and his new one, between superstar and street rapper.

title: Disclosure
label: Honest Jon's
description: Leipzig's Gunnar Wendel, better known as Kassem Mosse, abandons his house music background for thorny synthesizer sketches—fistfuls of gurgle and ping, sometimes beatless, and maddeningly absorbing.

title: Strands
label: Kranky
description: The Cleveland electronic musician has refined his minimalist techno to a frictionless peak. The keyboard patches on his latest are so physical that you can imagine holding them in your hand.

title: Goodbye Terrible Youth
label: Fat Possum
description: On his unabashedly personal new LP, indie rocker Gary McClure takes stock of his life, in distortion-heavy songs often filled with regret and loss, ugliness and shame.

title: Metal Box
label: Interscope
description: PiL's second album, Metal Box, is a near-perfect record that reinvents and renews rock in a manner that fulfilled post-punk’s promise(s) to a degree rivaled only by Joy Division on Closer.

title: Lady Wood
label: Island
description: Tove Lo's second album offers a platform for her to argue that self-destructive affairs of a particular sort of woman are a subject worthy of four-part concept albums.

title: ONEderful
label: Closed Sessions
description: The Chicago-bred, now Brooklyn-based beatmaker DJ Rude One's ONEderful is a grubby set of blood-in-your-mouth street raps, featuring Roc Marciano, Your Old Droog, Mr Muthafuckin eXquire, and more.

title: Hunted
label: 20 Buck Spin
description: Denver’s Khemmis traffic in longform doom metal, letting their anger spread gradually rather than unleashing it all in one torrent.

title: FLOTUS
label: Merge
description: The stalwart and defiantly odd Nashville band Lambchop's latest reinvention finds them embracing a Vocoder-drenched, largely electronic sound. It is as lush and gorgeous as any of their past work.

title: Tumblers From the Vault (1970–1972)
label: Rvng Intl.
description: All but unknown in the US, the adventurous trio Syrinx was among the first groups to embrace the Moog. RVNG has reissued their two albums along with a stunning live document.

title: All the Right Noises
label: Dial
description: Roman Flügel has explored hard techno, acid trance, willfully lunkheaded electro-house, and lyrical deep house over his prolific career, but this is the furthest he has strayed from the dancefloor.

title: Blood on the Tracks
label: Columbia
description: Bob Dylan’s moody 1975 epic is often referred to as his “breakup album,” but it might be his most welcoming LP, its music projecting an undeniable warmth.

title: Candida Cosmica
label: Dark Entries
description: The latest unearthed work from San Francisco disco innovator Patrick Cowley is a woozy, fascinating synth experiment with Candida Royalle, the feminist porn director and actress.

title: Rage & the Machine
label: EMPIRE
description: Joe Budden's latest album, produced almost entirely by AraabMUZIK, offers a concentrated dose of his usual fare: complex lyrical raps, bitter contempt for current hip-hop, and a list of grievances.

title: R M H Q: Headquarters
label: Grapefruit
description: In the early ’80s, New Zealand’s Roy Montgomery was part of foundational Flying Nun band the Pin Group. His first solo work since 2001 is a 4xLP set that, at its best, plays like a shadowy dream.

title: Secret Path
label: Arts & Crafts
description: Tragically Hip singer Gord Downie, diagnosed with a terminal brain tumor, offers an affecting album with Broken Social Scene's Kevin Drew about the plight of Canada's indigenous population.

title: Beyond Now
label: Motéma
description: After helping David Bowie realize his harrowing final statement Blackstar, saxophonist Donny McCaslin offers a bracing record with two Bowie tunes and a pair of covers of electronic acts.

title: Big Baby D.R.A.M.
label: Atlantic
description: After a string of EPs and some offbeat hits, rapper/singer D.R.A.M. arrives with his first full-length, a record filled with funny asides and sharp details and its fair share of memorable hooks.

title: Running Out of Love
label: Labrador
description: The latest from Swedish indie-pop stalwarts the Radio Dept. is the sound of a band rejecting indie-darling complacency for riskier, more mature territory, and the gamble pays off.

title: Dreamt Takes
label: 1080p
description: Queens-based beatmaker Luis summons early Warp-era IDM, when acts like Autechre, Speedy J, and Polygon Window crossbred hardcore and rave with the introspection of Tangerine Dream and Pink Floyd.

title: Mad Love.
label: Atlantic
description: After a decade of record label turmoil, the pop singer JoJo—of “Leave (Get Out)” fame—returns with a sincere third album, featuring guest spots from Alessia Cara, Wiz Khalifa, and Remy Ma.

title: Lazarus OST
label: Columbia
description: In the last year of his life, David Bowie completed his remarkable final album, Blackstar, as well as this curious jukebox musical for which he wrote a few new songs.

title: Lighthouse
label: Verve
description: Working with Michael League, the leader of the Brooklyn-based jazzy jam outfit Snarky Puppy, David Crosby releases his second solo record since returning from a 20-year hiatus.

title: Nordic Mediterranean Organization / Numerous Miscommunications Occur
label: Diagonal
description: On their full-length debut, the Norwegian and Spanish experimental duo N.M.O. deliver a zig-zagging array of unnerving forms, evoking militarization and irreverent playfulness in equal measure.

title: T.C.R. EP
label: Rough Trade
description: On their latest EP, the misanthropic British duo Sleaford Mods allow some air into their sound and frontman James Williamson turns some of his acrid tirades towards himself.

title: American Football
label: Polyvinyl
description: Coming after a 17-year hiatus, the second LP by American Football* *might be the most highly anticipated emo album ever made.

title: After Hours
label: Mixpak
description: On her debut LP, the Miami-born, NYC-based DJ and producer Jessica Gentile honors the nightlife that raised her. She draws on dancehall, Miami bass, and trap, with enough space to breathe and glitter.

title: Beyond the Fleeting Gales
label: Run for Cover
description: The indie rock trio Crying folds the bombast of mainstream '80s rock into their sound, and the results feel like a grinning inversion of the hetero-masculinity that’s often baked into such fireworks.

title: Moving Still
label: Pi
description: On his second album as a bandleader, the jazz trumpeter Jonathan Finlayson finds an exciting meeting ground of exploration and approachability. It’s the work of a composer on the rise.

title: Retribution
label: Unknown
description: Throat-singer Tanya Tagaq could be Canada’s unlikeliest crossover act. At a time when Canada is reckoning with the historic mistreatment of its indigenous population, her new LP demands retribution.

title: Joanne
label: Interscope
description: Now that her peers have caught up to her visual provocations, Lady Gaga seems less like an audacious pioneer than one among many, and Joanne feels tentative, an affront to the Gaga of yesteryear.

title: Popp
label: UOVOOO
description: On his fifth record since returning from hiatus in 2010, Oval's Markus Popp shows a side of, well, pop to his music that has often dwelled below the surface but never so overtly above it.

title: Whatever Forever
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Oozing Wound capture the energy of classic Slayer, Entombed, and punk-metal like Suicidal Tendencies, but it's hard to escape the feeling they are making fun of these guys as much as celebrating them.

title: Everything Feels Better Now
label: Triple Crown
description: From Indian Lakes’ fourth LP is mood music for the hopeless romantic, overwhelmed by the desire to connect but pining for the confidence to make the first move.

title: Savoy Motel
label: What's Your Rupture?
description: Savoy Motel recreate the sounds of the ’70s using the ’90s pastiche techniques of Beck, Ween and Royal Trux, compacting glam-rock, southern boogie, and Stax sax stabs into 8-bit videogame proportions.

title: Headache
label: self-released
description: Male Bonding's surprise-released third LP is another album about wounds that won’t heal. But at its best it brings a wizened new perspective to those same themes.

title: You Want It Darker
label: Columbia
description: Leonard Cohen's 14th studio album feels like a pristine, piously crafted last testament, the informed conclusion of a lifetime of inquiry.

title: End of the Century
label: Sire
description: For 1980’s End of the Century, the Ramones abandoned their tough, fast and loud dynamic to work with Phil Spector. It was one of the oddest pairings in punk history.

title: The Violent Sleep of Reason
label: Nuclear Blast
description: Although the veteran metal quintet sounded newly invigorated on its last two albums, T**he Violent Sleep of Reason is easily the most organic-sounding Meshuggah album in over 20 years.

title: Say Yes! A Tribute to Elliott Smith
label: American Laundromat
description: This tribute album is scattershot, as all such albums are, but the best moments find a new generation reckoning with what Smith's catalog means to them now.

title: Integrity Blues
label: RCA
description: The expansive, emotionally weathered *Integrity Blues is *perhaps Jimmy Eat World's best record since Bleed American, and even serves as its unlikely spiritual sequel.

title: Motor Earth
label: Drag City
description: The Chicago psych-rock band Axis:Sova indulge a fever for propulsion on Motor Earth, pairing thick waves of scuzzy guitar with the mechanized pulse of a tinny Roland drum machine.

title: These Systems Are Failing
label: Mute
description: These Systems Are Failing is Moby’s most furious album in twenty years, a return to his hardcore days, but it's still oddly cold and routine.

title: Woptober
label: Atlantic
description: On his second LP since being released from prison, Gucci revisits the darker, weirder style of his classic period but keeps the clear-eyed outlook of his new, healthier lifestyle.

title: EP A
label: Sister Polygon
description: This solo EP from Katie Alice Greer, singer in lauded D.C. punks Priests, mixes industrial textures and synth-pop. Her talent for composing moody collages of unraveling sound is a pleasant revelation.

title: Self Restraint
label: self-released
description: Self Restraint, the latest album from rapper Gods Wisdom of the New England-based Dark World collective, arrives feeling strangely dated, as if it’s an artifact from 2011 or 2012.

title: Fires on the Plain
label: Driftless
description: Matt Kivel's patient, close-miked folk music opens up slowly, revealing painful secrets the more time you spend listening to it.

title: Every Now & Then
label: Mom & Pop
description: On their second album, the Australian outfit go bigger and broader, unapologetically mining Primal Scream and the Madchester scene for inspiration.

title: Color
label: Tri Angle
description: On her Tri Angle debut, sound designer and producer-turned-musician Katie Gately twists odd, outré samples into big pop shapes.

title: WALLS
label: RCA
description: *WALLS *mostly finds Kings of Leon back in that mode of offering up fast-food “whoa-oh” singalongs and guitars that chime as distinctly as wallpaper.

title: Thirst 48 Pt. II
label: Interscope
description: The Compton rapper’s latest is a sequel to his 2014 debut mixtape. Boogie steps into the California sun, embracing a brighter sound with a flow that sharpens year after year.

title: Standard Nature
label: Profound Lore
description: Whether making black metal as Altar of Plagues or electronic music as WIFE, James Kelley has a taste for subversion, and his new WIFE EP surprises again by sounding downright joyful in spots.

title: Front Row Seat to Earth
label: Mexican Summer
description: The third full-length from singer/songwriter/producer Natalie Mering overflows with the misty sounds of late '60s folk and '70s AM radio, but her presence in these songs is modern and slyly knowing.

title: Sport
label: XL
description: The punk electronic music Powell makes is crude, queasy, sometimes shockingly ugly, and often quite funny, in a madcap, slightly threatening way. It thrills and it mystifies in equal measure.

title: Yermande
label: Ndagga
description: German techno giant Mark Ernestus delves deep into African music, and the result is drum-drunk and gorgeous, both techno-fast and dub-slow.

title: Yes Lawd!
label: Stones Throw
description: Yes Lawd! is another accomplishment in Anderson .Paak’s continued rise, a beautiful beat tape made with the producer Knxwledge that nods to classic Stones Throw duos.

title: Arctic Thunder
label: Peaceville
description: Darkthrone’s seventeenth studio album, Arctic Thunder, is a seamless, genre-hopping lexicon of death growls, doom dirges, and thrash runs as immediate as they are all-encompassing.

title: Remember Us to Life
label: Sire
description: Regina Spektor’s latest album takes the unabashed earnestness that has always marked her music and rewrites it in a somber, minor key.

title: Lubbock (on everything)
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: The artist Terry Allen made outlaw country from the vantage of the art world. Paradise of Bachelors have lavishly reissued his 1979 double album, a dreamscape that sways between country and folk.

title: Requiem for Hell
label: Temporary Residence
description: Mono's ninth album looks to nothing less than the mother of all epics, Dante's The Divine Comedy, for inspiration.

title: super low
label: Bayonet
description: Atlanta art-punks Warehouse build a tightly controlled chaos, relying on improvised collaboration to forge gems from dischord.

title: Building a Beginning
label: Jajulin
description: On Building A Beginning, Jamie Lidell unplugs his laptop for the most conventional R&B album of his career.

title: America’s National Parks
label: Cuneiform
description: Trumpeter Wadada Leo Smith's latest is an expansive and politically charged suite that pays tribute to official national parks as well as cultural zones not yet recognized by government decree.

title: Good Old Boys
label: Reprise
description: Randy Newman’s Good Old Boys is nothing less than a tour of Southern bigotry and pride in the 20th century. It remains as shocking, pristine, and regrettably relevant as the day it was released.

title: Coconut Oil
label: Atlantic
description: *Coconut Oil, *Lizzo's first release under Atlantic, is her ode to body positivity, self-love and the trials of getting to the point where you believe you deserve it.

title: High Bias
label: Drag City
description: At his best, Purling Hiss frontman Mike Polizze simultaneously embraces, tweaks, and subverts all kinds of vintage garage, punk, and grunge moves. This is their most classic-rock record so far.

title: Adieux Au Dancefloor
label: Cititrax
description: Marie Davidson is a spoken-word poet and electronic artist who is also one half of the duo Essaie Pas. Her third solo release, examining club culture, shows near-exponential growth in her abilities.

title: COW / Chill Out, World!
label: Kompakt
description: C**OW has some of the Orb’s most gentle moments to date, eschewing ambient house for ambient music, pure and simple.

title: Home OST
label: Italians Do It Better
description: Made for a Belgian coming-of-age tale, Home is the latest film soundtrack by Johnny Jewel. It features new Chromatics and Symmetry music, plus eight ambient tracks, but is strangely mild-mannered.

title: Philosophy of the World
label: Light in the Attic
description: The Shaggs' Philosophy of the World became an enduring classic for its beguiling amateurism. But in its 2016 reissue, it's easier to hear the darkness and sadness behind the Wiggin sisters' story.

title: Coming Home (Original Ghanaian Highlife & Afrobeat Classics 1967-1981)
label: Strut
description: This two-disc retrospective touches on several phases of Ghanaian vocalist Pat Thomas' career, pulling highlife, swing jazz, Afrobeat, psychedelic rock, reggae, funk, and disco into his joyful orbit.

title: Outer
label: Polydor
description: After perfecting anthemic dancefloor fantasies with fine-tuned tracks like “Yoohoo,” Dusky offer a sentimentalist hodge-podge designed to prove that their mettle extends beyond the dancefloor.

title: Cashmere
label: Customs
description: The transatlantic duo of Heems (ex-Das Racist) and Riz MC (actor Riz Ahmed) link up for an album of politically-charged rap that's both thought-provoking and genuinely fun.

title: Marked for Death
label: Sargent House
description: Rundle has made her name performing mournful, minor key compositions, swelling with gothic drama, and her latest is her heaviest and most uplifting work yet.

title: There Is No Right Time
label: Aus
description: The debut album from Yorkshire house producer Ewan Smith is a collection of daydreamy mood pieces. Stepping up the sound design, these melancholy tracks highlight Smith’s expressive sensibility.

title: Complete Third
label: Omnivore
description: Big Star's never-completed third album is enshrined in a triple-disc box that contains all known recordings from the 1974 sessions and finally makes sense of all the chaos.

title: The Altar
label: Harvest
description: Banks' The Altar has a lot in common with the alt-R&B singer's breakthrough Goddess, including its fatal flaw: its attempts to position her as edgy or dangerous, despite all evidence to the contrary.

title: Cody
label: Epitaph
description: The California foursome follow their pop-punk breakthrough Never Hungover Again with the more grown-up and measured Cody.

title: NOTU_URONLINEU
label: Hyperdub
description: Working under his new alias DVA [Hi:Emotions], Leon Smart smears the edges of the human and artificial, the organic and the electronic, as if trying to sketch out the dimensions of a digital self.

title: Ruminations
label: Nonesuch
description: *Ruminations *is a record like none other in Conor Oberst’s catalog, stunning for how utterly alone he sounds.

title: Shit Don’t Stop
label: So Way Out Tha Innerprize
description: In a crowded—and excellent—year for West Coast hip-hop, G Perico stands out as one of the most promising newcomers.

title: Heart Like a Levee
label: Merge
description: On his sixth album as Hiss Golden Messenger, M.C. Taylor's lifelong theme remains intact: What happens when you feel a distance from the thing that’s meant to sustain you?

title: Day Breaks
label: Blue Note
description: The restive jazz star, who went on to work with Jack White, Danger Mouse, and others after her multiplatinum debut, returns with a no-frills record that fades into the background without much fuss.

title: Throwback to the Future
label: Tommy Boy
description: Producer Prince Paul and Digable Planets rapper Ladybug Mecca contribute to this fusion of NYC-style hip-hop and Brazilian music.

title: Revolution Radio
label: Reprise
description: Over the course of 26 years, Green Day have gone from pop punks to rock stars. Their latest, however, has little effect on their legacy and lapses into pandering, embarrassing lyrical misfires.

title: While They Were Sleeping
label: Metal Blade
description: The eighth album from the wildly experimental Brooklyn metal group doesn't quite blaze trails on par with the band's classic catalog, but they are still genuinely searching for new expressions.

title: Requiem
label: Sub Pop
description: The ritualistically anonymous GOAT return with a double album of psychedelia rendered primarily with acoustic elements. Though still veiled, they reveal more of their heart and personality than ever.

title: Sonoran Depravation
label: Relapse
description: Arizona’s Gatecreeper stand out not by aping one particular style of death metal, but by acting as a polyglot of various classic bands. Sonoran Depravation is their unwavering debut LP.

title: Root/Void
label: Woodsist
description: The latest from the prolific psych-folk duo comes courtesy of Woods' Woodsist imprint, and the higher profile coincides with some of their more memorable tunes.

title: Rhythm Nation 1814
label: A&M
description: After her 1986 album Control and its assertion of her identity as an artist, Janet Jackson was thinking big. Rhythm Nation 1814 is a thrilling mix of social messaging and dancefloor pleasure.

title: Private Energy
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: The latest from Roberto Carlos Lange's electronic pop project is a melodic and beautifully produced meditation on identity and the difficulty of connection.

title: Cold Summer
label: Roc Nation
description: In the wake of some professional tumult, the snap and ratchet producer stages a solid comeback with more varied production and plenty of celebration.

title: Sorceress
label: Nuclear Blast
description: On their 12th full-length album, the Swedish metal institution have never sounded more comfortable with their full-on prog transition, which works both for and against them.

title: Be Here Now
label: Big Brother
description: Oasis’ third album from 1997 was always more circus than substance. The bloated and indulgent remaster only reinforces it as one of the most agonizing listening experiences in pop music.

title: Big Boat
label: Jemp
description: Phish is not known for their studio work. But for a group of musicians whose sole value has always been the simple pleasure of making music, everyone here sounds noticeably vacant.

title: Three
label: Republic
description: As Sarah Barthel and Josh Carter inch toward the mainstream, their plaintive and gloomy* Three* feels less like an album and more like postcards from the eye of an emotional hurricane.

title: Everywhere at the End of Time
label: History Always Favours the Winners
description: This new LP is the first in a six-album series from ambient artist James Leyland Kirby. It’s an extreme continuation of the concept—memory loss—that guided his 2011 masterpiece, An Empty Bliss...

title: Lamentations
label: self-released
description: Moses Sumney has a gorgeous voice that is as intricate as it is intimate. His latest EP comes and goes too fast, but is still a welcome window into the electro-soul folk singer's private world.

title: Serpent Music
label: Pan
description: Like James Ferraro or Dean Blunt, the Turin-based artist uses unsettling percussive loops and field recordings to create a mood as if lost in a strange urban landscape.

title: Head Carrier
label: Play It Again Sam
description: While not as egregiously baffling as Indie Cindy, the latest from the ’90s indie icons is nonetheless a middling effort missing all kinds of dynamics the Pixies used to offer.

title: Farewell, Starlite!
label: KTTF
description: After big-name co-signs for the smooth, self-made producer and vocalist Francis Farewell Starlite, his latest album doesn't quite live up to expectations.

title: Fires Within Fires
label: Neurot
description: The heavy Bay Area band’s eleventh and latest full-length is also their briefest by a sizable margin. It sags often, but Fires With Fires ends with a staggering exhibition of quiet power.

title: A Seat at the Table
label: Columbia
description: Solange’s new record is stunning, a thematically unified and musically adventurous statement on the pain and joy of black womanhood.

label: Smalltown Supersound
description: With 13 albums under their belt, the Norwegian experimentalists continue to haunt the dark, underexplored basements of electro-improvisational music.

title: The Electric Lucifer
label: Telephone Explosion
description: In the 1960s and ’70s, Bruce Haack led a double life. By day, he made children’s music. By night, demonic electronica. This reissue presents his most accomplished work in all its end-times glory.

title: Light We Made
label: Vagrant
description: Following 2013’s bludgeoning The Things We Think We’re Missing, the Doylestown, P.A. band returns with a cleaner, efficient, and more stylish sound.

title: Monologue
label: Aaron Abernathy Music
description: The session musician and leader of Nat Turner goes big on his first official LP, creating a spiritually rich and soulful autobiographical story.

title: Blood Bitch
label: Sacred Bones
description: The Norwegian avant-gardist’s most atmospheric and filmic album draws on several traditions: vampire movies, the cross-hairs of art and pop, and the lineage of artwork made of menstrual blood.

title: Red Horse, White Mule / Opium Musick / Raag Manifestos / Jack Rose / I Do Play Rock and Roll / Dr. Ragtime and His Pals
label: Three Lobed
description: Vinyl reissues of six albums from the late Jack Rose further solidify his place as a brilliant steel string guitar innovator.

title: Rheia
label: Deathwish
description: Rheia not only transforms the Belgian metal band's own abilities, but the breadth of the much heralded—and derided—black metal-shoegaze fusion.

title: Fio da Memória
label: Cumbancha
description: It's been six years since the Brazilian singer's debut. Now she returns with an album that both utilizes and breaks free of samba and bossa nova classicism with deep, downtempo beats.

title: Atrocity Exhibition
label: Warp
description: Atrocity Exhibition can be seen as the third work in a trilogy that began with XXX. Here, Danny Brown's songs of pain and release are accompanied by dense sonics from all over the musical map.

title: Schaum
label: Faitiche
description: Experimental electronic producer Jan Jelinek partners with vibraphonist Masayoshi Fujita to create gorgeous clouds of shifting sound.

title: Quebec Place
label: self-released
description: The young Maryland rapper presents a deft, stylish, and unique introduction to his career.

title: Real Enemies
